subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: Hi Paige, I m no linguist, but my understanding is that sounds that are not contrasted in the language environment in which a person spends the first few years
messageBody:
Hi Paige,

I'm no linguist, but my understanding is that sounds that are not
contrasted in the language environment in which a person spends the
first few years of life are quite difficult to learn to distinguish
later on. Think about native Chinese speakers who have difficulty
distinguishing 'l' and 'r'. (Contrast between colors, on the other
hand, is determined physiologically by the sensitivity of each of the
three different types of cones in the retina to variations in the
frequency of absorbed light. People who are red-green colorblind will
be so no matter what their cultural environment. Question: why doesn't
the color brown appear in the rainbow? Answer: the "color" brown is an
artifact of the human visual system, created in response to other
colors in the visual field. It is not possible to illuminate a movie
screen in a darkened theater with just the color brown. But I
digress...)

When I learned Hindi 20 years ago (as a Peace Corps volunteer in Fiji)
our language trainers had to teach us where to place our tongues and
exactly how to push air through our mouths in order for us to
approximate the 4 different 't' sounds and the 4 different 'd' sounds
in their language. (Look for the 4 t's and 4 d's in the Hindi alphabet
here: http://www.omniglot.com/writing/hindi.htm) If we got these
sounds wrong, we inadvertently spoke either nonsense or unintended
words, always a source of hilarity. It took many months before we
could consistently hear the differences between these sets of
phonemes.

These same trainers laughed at my friend Doug's name, because they
couldn't distinguish it from 'dog'. They advised him to adopt another
name so no one would laugh at him. When we asked how on Earth people
who could hear the differences between 4 nearly identical t's and 4
nearly identical d's could not hear the difference between 'dog' and
'Doug' they just smiled and shrugged.

I'll have a few things to say about the Fijian language soon as well
(in reference to QS letter #21)...

Ted


On Nov 25, 2007 11:59 AM, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I have been on vacation and am trying to catch up with what's been going
> on.
>
> I agree with Moira. I use all three sounds: Awl, Ah and On. In fact, I
> really don't understand what some people mean when they say they can't hear
> the difference between Awl and On. It strikes me in a similar way as if
> they said they can't distinguish between blue and green. Obviously, the
> boundary between the two colors is somewhat ambiguous, but most of us have a
> clear enough idea of what blue is versus what green is.
>
> I have thought that those who say they can't hear the difference actually
> just means they don't use the Awl sound, i.e. they pronounce words such as
> "all" with the On sound. I expect that they can hear the difference if they
> listen closely to someone pronouncing Awl versus On even if it is not a
> distinction they make in their own speech.
>
> This whole thread seems to have started as a method to enable a dictionary
> to have all spelling variants placed together alphabetically. Rather than
> throwing out a phoneme that many of us feel quite strongly about, it makes
> more sense to me that if there is a variant spelling that will not be next
> to the others simply put in a note directing the reader to the other
> spelling as in: "see also: _______."
>
> I also feel strongly about the continued availability of "Wh". I am sure
> that those who don't use it don't miss it, but I can assure you reading the
> QS news with nary a "wh" to be seen is noticed by me every time I come
> across a word where I would use it. I actually seem more aware of its
> absence in writing than I am in hearing others who don't use "wh" in their
> speech.
>
> Paige
>
>
> Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
>
> As a speaker of RP, I can't agree to the merger of Awl Ah and On. My
> pronunciation makes full use of all three as distinct sounds.
> It also does with Wool & Ooze but losing one of those two would not be much
> of a hardship.
> The distinction between those sounds is quite small and not significant and
> is very much like the different sounds of Schwa.
>
> Moira
>
>
>
>
>
